UPDATE: Added Ninjaflex buttons

The Adafruit 2.2" PiTFT HAT is a perfect mini display for all sorts of Raspberry Pi projects. In this project, we're going to 3D print an enclosure to fit the Pi A+ and the 2.2" PiTFT.

With this project, we can make a small astrobox that puts our 3D printer on the Wifi Network. The Astroprint image is easy to install and lets us control the printer with any device on the network.

Full Tutorial
https://learn.adafruit.com/3d-printed-2-2-pitft-raspberry-pi-a-plus-enclosure/3d-printing

We put together the enclosure in Fusion 360 using sketches. The 3 parts snap fit together with friction and most of the ports are accessible.

The parts fit nicely on the Printrbot Simple Metal and You can pick one up from the Adafruit Shop!

The Zebra plate from"Print-In-Z" makes removing the prints much easier and beats blue painters tape.

The parts print with no support material and takes just under 2 hours.

They came out looking exceptional using CURA with the default settings and slicing profile.

You only need to solder the socket header to the GPIO pinout on the display.

It’s a lot easier if you tack the header to the PCB and a use pana-vise to keep it sturdy while you solder.

The PiTFT snaps on top of the Raspberry Pi and 3D printed spacer keeps the two PCBs in place.

It slides into the case at an angle and clips on the edges keep them from coming out.

Ports line up nicely with the cutouts and everything just snap fits together.

Ninjaflex make great rubber actuators for the buttons on the Display.

Keep the protective film on until the last step!

Place the cover over the display and press the edges into the case to close it up.

Use any 5V battery or power source with a microUSB cable, and now we have our mini astrobox.

The PiTFT's make great displays for small Raspberry Pi projects.

But be sure to check out the guide linked below for a full tutorial.
https://learn.adafruit.com/3d-printed-2-2-pitft-raspberry-pi-a-plus-enclosure/3d-printing

Fits on the end of the aluminum platform of a Solidoodle 3 or 4.

Reduces wobble along the X-axis that is caused by a Z-screw that is not perfectly straight and/or off center.

I would say that this change has had the biggest impact on the quality of prints. I recommend this or one of the platform stabilizers that inspired this for any Solidoodle printer.

Print Stabilizer parts ( all ) and rod ends from the stl files.

I used ABS with 20% infill, 0.2mm layers for small parts, 0.3mm layers for large parts.

Printed parts:

  • solidoodle_aluminum_platform_stabilizer_v1.stl

    This file contains all the parts that attach to the bed platform. (print with the flat side down)

  • solidoodle_rod_ends_for_aluminum_platform_stabilizer.stl

    This file has parts for one rod end. (so print 2x)

Other parts:

  • 2 x 6mm diameter rod ( 12 cm long) I used aluminum.
  • 8 x M4 bolts (for rod holders)
  • 2 x M4 bolts (for bearings / rod ends )
  • 10 M4 nuts
  • ABS glue (made from acetone and ABS scraps). Contact Cement would probably work well for ABS too
  • 2 x 608 "Skate" bearings

Assembly, rod ends

  1. Lightly sand the surface that the ball bearings will rest on so they are even
  2. Ensure rods to be glued are clean. Perhaps, a light sanding to give the glue a better surface to adhere to.
  3. Glue rod to rod end parts and clamp and leave to dry overnight
  4. Insert ferrule into bearing
  5. Insert bearing into bearing holder on rod end
  6. Bolt together

Assembly, Bed Platform attachment

  1. Insert nuts into their slots on the bed and add the clips
  2. Use clips and bolts to attach rods to the platform attachment.
    Do not tighten the clips yet!
  3. Slide rod ends towards the center so the bed platform attachment can be installed
  4. Slide the Bed Platform attachment on to the end on the aluminum bed platform.
  5. Slide rods outwards evenly until the bearing ear in contact with the printers frame.
  6. Tighten slide rod clamps.

Test:

  1. Use your control software to move the Bed up and Down and check the following

    • bearings stay in contact with frame
    • bed doesn't move side to side
    • nothing impedes the motion of the bed, bearings, rods, etc.
  2. Run some test prints

title: Landing gear for spedix s250 BNF

description.text:
I broke two of the stock landing gear within a few days. I remixed the MHQ2 landing gear to match the stock gear height and to clear the battery mounting plate.
This landing gear bolts to the pdb with m3 screws and locknuts.
It looks like these may fit the kit version with the carbon plates but I have not verified this.
Update: After a few pogo landings on asphalt, the first version cracked as shown in the gallery.
New version uploaded with additional material in the top of the model.
Feedback welcome!

Use m3 x 14 machine screws and attach to the power distribution board. See pics for placement.
My print was on a da vinci with xyzware at 100% size.

title: Rep 2 Filament Sliding Rotating Bearing Guide

description.text:
A three part rotating, sliding bearing guide for any size filament roll. I designed this for our Makerbot Repicator 2, but I'm sure it could be used on other machines. The filament guide pivots on a bearing, the bearing mount slides on the bracket, and the bracket rotates to align with either the left or right filament roll.
For the bearing I used a McMaster Carr P/N 60355K503 bearing. The bearing presses in and requires leverage (ie: an arbor press, don't use a hammer). I mounted the assembly level with and 1.25" next to the factory sheet metal guide tube mounts (thru the plastic and into the sheet metal) using a #10 sheet metal screw, and predrilled with a 0.155" dia drill bit. The mounting location both penetrates the sheet metal for a good fastener anchor, and is close to but clears the factory guide tube mounts when the assembly rotates.

Materials LIst:
1x No. R4 Bearing (McMaster Carr P/N 60355K503)
1x #10 x 3/8"L Screw (McMaster Carr P/N 90190A240 for 100)
1x #10 Washer, thin (McMaster Carr P/N 90126A514 for 100)
1x #10 x 1"L Screw (McMaster Carr P/N 90190A247 for 100)

I printed PLA on high resolution with rafts, supports, and bridges, with %50 infill. When mounting the ball bearing (press fit), I shimmed the gap under the Bearing Mount with a plastic spatula to keep the Bearing Mount lip from snapping off as the bearing was pressed in. The Bearing Post tabs are a bit fragile, so don't "test" them with your fingers, and carefully push the Bearing Post into the pre-seated ball bearing. The Bearing Mount fits into the groove on the Bracket, and is captured by a 3/8" long #10 screw (and #10 washer) that threads into the printed screw hole on the back of the Bearing Mount. As described, I mounted the assembly centered and offset from the stock sheet metal guide tube mounts, on the "right" (facing the back of the printer) and close but with enough room to rotate the unit without hitting the sheet metal guide tube holders. I predrilled 0.155" for the mounting screw, and tightened to "snug" but left it loose enough for the assembly to rotate.

title: Mustang Hoonicorn Bodyshell for XMods Evo Chassis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is that Hoonicorn model I just posted, but scaled down slightly, widened and hollowed out to fit over an XMods Evolution R/C chassis. It's a very tight fit and PLA is probably not the most robust material for an R/C body, but it's no heavier than the stock bodyshell and so it has no real effect on performance. I couldn't get the drive pin shape in the wheels centers quite right, so I had to drill them out and that DOES have an affect on performance (drivetrain loss means I can't get full speed or wheelspin with these wheels on). You can still rip skids when you pair this body with the stock wheels: https://vine.co/v/ej9DTPPddWz

Print the body, front clip, and 4 wheels all with support.

You can find my rough model of the XMods Evo chassis in the .blend file if you want reference for building your own custom bodyshell.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Direct Extruder with X carriage for E3D hotend, full cooling.

title: Prusa i3 Dual Direct Extruder E3D hotend

description.text:
Dual direct extruder for Prusa i3 with E3D V5 hotend.

Key features:

  • Bi-delta wing shaped X carriage structure resulted in a lightweight design with high X rigidity.
  • Symmetric design with minimum bending momentum load on X axis.shaft.
  • Relaxed YZ constrain to decouple X axis motion with YZ plane.
  • Robust cooling mount with E3D fan shroud and blower cooling nozzle.
  • locking lever on extruder arm for easy filament handling
  • easily accessible filament path
  • belt clamp with tensioning capability

BOM

Extruder

  • 2pcs MK7 extruder gear
  • 2pcs spring
  • 2pcs 624ZZ bearing
  • 2pcs NEMA17 stepper
  • 2pcs E3D V5 hotend, aka, long distance version

Cooling

  • 5015s.blower fan, 12v, 52x52x15mm
  • 2pcs 40mmX10mm 12v fan

Linear motion

  • 3pcs LM8UU linear bearing
  • 2pcs U shape pin made from paper clip pin for top LM8UU mount

Fasteners

  • stepper motor 6pcs M3X20 socket head, 2pcs M3X8 countersunk flat head
  • E3D clamping: 4pcs M3X20 or M3X25
  • extruder spring tensioner: 2pcs M3X16
  • extruder locking lever 2pcs M3X16
  • extruder bearing: 2pcs M4X16
  • 40mm fan mount: 10pcs M3X16
  • 50mm blower bottom mount: 1pc M3X25
  • belt clamp/tensioner 4pcs M3X10 or longer as needed
  • M3 nuts and washers as needed

Build:

The complete build plate file: dual_direct_extruder_e3d_all_parts.stl

All parts have been designed for easy printing with minimum or no support. Fan shroud mounting holes can be M3 tapped for mounting without nut.

Video: https://youtu.be/QD0Btv66SBs

remixed_from.title: Servo Bracket with 60mm LED light ring mount and remixed parts

description.text:
This is a servo bracket for auto bed leveling, designed specifically for the Folger Tech Prusa i3. I made some minor modifications to MindRealm's great design to better suit my needs. It now integrates an X-endstop mount in addition to the original features. Also, a modified servo arm that should be more compatible with different servos, and a variant that places the Z probe switch on the opposite side of the arm (needed when the arm interferes with the X switch). Finally, the top piece of the bracket is designed to allow for a tighter fit to the extruder motor.

UPDATE 8/27/15

  • V2 bracket includes a zip tie slot for securing the servo.
  • New bracket design hides the X-endstop for a neater look.

UPDATE 8/28/15

  • Added the endstopper for the X-endstop switch to bump into.

Printed with ABS, 0.24mm layers, and 75% infill.

I highly recommend using ABS! My first print with PLA dropped the servo due to high bed temperature, and the Z probe arm warped.

  • Insulating the arm and using a zip tie around the servo should solve these issues with PLA.

UPDATE 8/27/15

  • The "hidden" bracket design requires supports.

description.text:
My youngest son does not speak and spends most of his time in a wheelchair when moving about. His school started using an iPad to supplement his speech and looking at some of the prices for mounts out there, I decided I would create one!

This mount would likely need to change depending on your wheelchair if you choose to use it, since piping may be a bit different. The hole for the pipe is oversized as I used some rubber placemat material to wrap around the tube to prevent it from being scratched and it gave it an excellent grip! The iPad is velcroed to the top plate, and seems to hold well!

The gooseneck that I used is this one:

http://www.amazon.com/Stage-Microphone-19-inch-Gooseneck-Black/dp/B00080KNG8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1440721630&sr=8-1&keywords=On+Stage+Microphone+19-inch+Gooseneck%2C+Black&pebp=1440721632588&perid=0HFHHQBQQNKR42E9AP77

The small hardware are standard 4-40 nuts and bolts. The larger bolt for the gooseneck will vary depending on the gooseneck used and if you purchase an adapter or not.

With the iPad on it, it seems to sag a bit, but it is manageable. It will work until I find a stronger neck. Something to note.. there is a difference between the US and UK style microphone goose necks. Oddly, the US versions use a different thread pattern that you can't go to a hardware store (at least around here) and find hardware that will work with it. I had to get adapters to make it work for me. Also, the hole for the large bolt is not large enough for a socket.. purposefully did that so one has to use pliers to tighten it and ensures not to overtighten it. A user can then unscrew the gooseneck from the top if you should need to fold up the wheelchair.

It is not an elegant solution by any means... but it is my first real project created in CAD, so being a total n00b I am impressed with it! :) Note: I apologize for the orientation... I will fix that when I get the chance (and figure out what orientation the parts SHOULD be in when saved!)

The bottom mount parts I printed with 4 shells, 75% infill out of PLA and found it to be pretty robust. The top mount I printed at about 40% infill, 2 top/bottom shells and 4 outer shells, PLA as well.

comments.text: For the sag you can twist the neck to make it tighter and/or straighten a wire hanger and put it inside the gooseneck.

description.text:
Create coffee stencil with your text on it.
Use OpenSCAD 2015.03 and stencil fonts.

Use Customizer OR:

  • Install stencil font, or you will be unable to use letters with isolated perimeters (O or B)
  • Open coffee_stencil.scad in OpenSCAD 2015.03
  • Edit Text variable
  • Set desired font name as Font variable
  • Adjust Spacing if needed.
  • Set Height of stencil (2.2mm ought to be enough to anybody)
  • Set diameter by changing Dia (typical values are 62mm for small cup, and 83mm for mug)
  • Render and export
  • Print with PLA (Layer height = 0.2, perimeters = 2)

Avoid exposing stencil to high temperatures (by plunging into hot coffee for example)

Highly edited version of the original from Gyrobot and the version from MarcoAlici with independent shaft sizes.(see Remixed from).

Now contains many comments and named parameters.

Features:

  • Top and bottom independent hole diameters
  • Smooth exterior spirals for coupling
  • Hex or square captive nuts
  • Recessed bolt heads
  • Optimisations for no support printing
  • D shafts optional

Notes:

  • 100% fill for structural strength
  • PLA is less brittle than ABS for this structure.
  • Print with no support (unless spiral degrees are very high).
  • The longer and thinner the spirals are - the more flexible the coupler will be.
    • So increase Spiral degrees for longer arms and Number of Spirals for thinner arms.
  • Top and Bottom captive bolts are the same so there is no wobbling at high spin rates.

Can be made flexible by treating a PLA object to a Carburettor Cleaner bath to make it even more flexible.
See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:98268 for instructions.

Carburettor Cleaner is primarily 30% each of Methanol, Toluene and Acetone. (The Acetone and Methanol do not affect PLA much). In this case its the Toluene which is causing the PLA to expand in size (20% increase in volume) and therefore become more flexible.

However its an organic solvent and dries out. It also weakens the PLA material. Effects are not permanent.

Reference: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,281724

title: Reuleaux Polygon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Reuleaux polygon is a 2D shape of constant width. Use the customizer to create a Reuleaux polygon of any number of vertices!

To construct a Reuleaux polygon, draw a regular polygon with an odd number of vertices (triangle, pentagon, heptagon, etc.). Then, each side is replaced by an arc who's center is the vertex opposite the side being replaced (notice that the sides of a polygon with an even number of sides does not have an opposite vertex).

Customize the number of vertices, width, and thickness of the Reuleaux polygon. Then chose whether you would like to engrave the top or bottom face with the number of vertices, and customize depth and size of the engraved features.

After numerous y-shifted prints, decided to try and sort out a good spool holder and was impressed with the item I derived this from. Will work towards a customizable item, but in the mean time providing these parts in case anyone wants to build one.

The only non-printed part in the final build are skateboard bearings, 8/22/7 size, which can be sourced relatively cheaply. These provide the friction free rotation you want.

All items created using OpenSCAD but not really ready for uploading the files as they're a bit of a mix of solutions and somewhat tweaked rather than fully parametric at present.

After building this and then attempting to hold the spool in place on the wheels I eventually redesigned this thing using other people's design as inspiration, but also making it parametric. You can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:990972

description.text:
I saw some beautiful designs of apple watch and iphone combo chargers so I set out to make one for a 360 and a phone. This was the first generation. I printed it but had to toss it at the airport, don't ask, so no pics of final. Anyway first gen had some issues, I used the board and coil for the watch charger from one of these. http://www.amazon.com/Wireless-Yootech%C2%AE-Charging-Blackberry-Qi-Enabled/dp/B00NWMI07S/ref=sr_1_2?s=wireless&ie=UTF8&qid=1440725976&sr=1-2&keywords=qi+charger

Also stl's are in cm so if importing in mm scale by 10.

Charger was okay but would keep 360 screen on and shut off charger so if the watch was on the charger too long would actually kill the battery. Another annoyance is that the 360 screen when charging is always horizontal, next design will charge watch in that direction.

I ordered a single coil and a 3 coil qi from amazon and am planning a double wireless charger.

http://www.amazon.com/Itian-Wireless-Charging-Single-Samsung/dp/B00V2HL4Y6/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1440725532&sr=8-1&keywords=diy+qi&pebp=1440725536581&perid=093R6D8254V9W6APR8ZK

phone stand was designed for one plus one, generally phones with cases will not work, again since next one will be wireless should fix this.
make sure to follow me to see the next version

All parts can be printed without support except qi holder, this will need support could be printed in two directions, suggest top has hole for charger.
Printed all parts with layer thickness of 0.2 mm.
All parts should snap together, I would first place the coil and board into the holder, then snap the cover on. Next snap the arm to the holder. Slide the bottom on to the arm and phone stand to the bottom of the watch stand. run micro usb cables to desired points. I would suggest using a right angle micro usb with the watch portion.

author: ghioki

description.text: A tap for collecting sap to make maple/pine/spruce syrup

1. print
  2. drill a hole into desired tree about 6cm deep
  3. hang a metal bucket or something to collect sap on the hook
  4. boil the sap on an outdoor grill/fire(can be done inside, but the steam that rises can damage the ceiling or make smoke alarms go off)
  5. pour white sugar, brown sugar, and even a little water of desired amount
  6. CAN AT ONCE.
  7. put in freezer for 7 days

I think mz4250's work is incredible and I have communicated with him several times, and I just don't want to cause too many ripples and cause too much of a problem for WotC, causing them to request that mz4250 takes all of his models down permanently.

author: mb20music

description.text: I wanted to know if my Air Condtitioning was running or not at a quick glance. So I made this mini turbine that uses magnets to stick to a vent. It spins freely when the AC fan is running.

Printed in Cura at .2 layer height and 15% infill. Used .05 inch diameter solder for the axle. When you put the solder (or whatever) thourgh all the pieces, pull the turbine down (away from the base) a bit enough to bend the axle. This will allow a better spin for the blade. As for the magnets, they were 1/4in X 1/4in cyclinder magnets. Simply put them in the holes and added tape over them.

title: Zuul Racehound Superbeast Tough Guard AeroGuard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Fits both Racehound or Superbeast. This 4mm thick aeroguards keep the propellers out during a crash. Since the Zuul can fold, the propellers have a great chance of protruding into the body cavity. This will break props before it reaches your electronics! Includes a file with a port on the left side to access the flight controller to tune.
Print on its side to orient the infill for a stronger part. Can also print upright to increase the strength around the standoffs. For upright printing, PLA is recommended.

title: GoPro Hero 3/3+ Flanged Lens Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: LayerLens ended up ripping the rubbery ring around the lens off, so this Flanged ring is a perfect fit (might need to sand off the elephant feet). It provides some light shielding and protection to your GoPro lens. The one picture shows the hit it took after a bad crash. The tight fit is needed to prevent it from popping off. No adhesive material is needed. There is also a normal ring that is similar in size to the original. I use it when I want to use another layer lens.
The fit is intended to be very tight. sand down the inside edge near the lens until it fits over the small stubs on the GoPro.

title: Replacement utensil separator for GE dishwasher silverware basket

description.text:
This is part #765 for silverware basket, WD28X10177 (AP3860905)
These things have tiny little tabs that serve as axles which fatigue and break. I made this replacement for my own dishwasher, and enlarged the holes to accept silverware with wider handles.

Suggested print material is ABS for heat resistance and durability in the dishwasher.
Measured the OEM item and went through several iterations to match the original.

title: QAV PDB skid plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A thick durable protective cover for the PDB board that sits on the underbelly of a QAV250. The vulnerable board is at risk when landing on any hard surface. Protect the valuables with this skid plate! Has holes to secure the battery lead with a small zip tie to relieve stress off the PDB. 0.35 infill made a super strong plate that survived a full speed crash on asphalt!
The mounting holes are for made to accommodate large M3 screws heads. Even without screwing the board on, the sides grip the PDB strong enough for it to stay on in the roughest of flights.

description.text:
From the 1970 TV series "UFO". Modeled in Solidworks from a few pictures I found on the net. Printed on the Makers Tool Works "MiniMax" printer. The dome should be clear plastic and I am planning on hacking up a fake security camera dome. If and when I succeed I will post the update. All STL's have been netfab'ed for errors.

The main body has built in supports with break-away slits. Be careful removing the support it is easy to split the thin vanes. The dome will need to be printed with support turned on. I printed with PLA and attached all the pieces with Super Glue.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3gjWgUqljc2

Finally found a good use for the glow in the dark and purple PLA I had sitting around. Fairly simple model but it turned out well so I'm sharing it here. It might also look good with translucent material in the center and purple edges. Share your prints if you try this model out!
I used simplify 3D's dual extrusion wizard. Printed on my ffcp. 15% fill, printed in place on glass with hairspray.
fan shroud

Slips on over the rear or front posts.

Can't fit 6" props unless you put the volt meter on the inside. 5" fit and are shown in pictures.

A few files included.. the Moment of Inspiration files, and the stl files.

the STL's are marked _25mm, _30mm, _32mm

Which corresponds to how tall it is. I didn't make it the full 35mm because of the screw heads and the zip tie I have.

title: Tapping Wrench
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For holding hole-tapping bits.
Cheaper than any other wrench if you only want to get a couple of specifically-sized taps made from good steel.

• Print out the two parts, heavy infill would be a good idea.
    ---(Ideally you could cast or machine the pinching block out of scrap metal, though the block might not even be necessary)
  • Ream out the 8mm hole with a drill bit, or tap it with your bolt itself.
  • Insert your bolt or studding.
    ---(Optional step for studding: drill a hole in it and stick something like a pin in it as a handle - pictured for an idea)
  • Use the bolt to drag an M8 nut into the captive nut slot.
  • Clamp it onto the square end of a tap, and go cut some threads!

title: Airsoft Mini Claymore
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I once bought a Airsoft Claymore and loved the tactical options it gave. But it´s big and expencive. So i wanted to create one that is cheap and small so you can carry multiple one´s.

You need 2 micetraps for the arms, wire (which i drilled double) to attach the mousetraps through the holes in the body.

You can use the metall pins of the mousetraps to attach the door and lever - but it will look nicer and work better with an M3 and an M5 screw.

The shooting mechanism is not perfect up to now, but with tape it will already shoot around 5 meters which is enough to cover doors and little ways. Iam still trying some options to improve this.

The lever works like i charm for me now after trying LOTS of different mechanism, you can use the loop on the down part to guide the string to the front of the mine.

You HAVE TOO make a little pocket for the bbs so they dont fall out the mechanism. I recomend to just fill the BBs after setting up the claymore.

If you like my work and it saved you time or money, please consider supporting me on patreon or leaving my youtube channel a visit - i appreciate it!

https://www.patreon.com/MangoAirsoft

https://www.youtube.com/user/vhwie
All parts have a smooth side on which it can be easily printed.

comments.author: esahc

title: Wild Catz... with Jaws that Bite and Growl!

description.text:
Another thing that bites... like my Sharkz / Crocz / EagleZ this design also bites things! (NO SUPPORT REQUIRED)

However, Wild Catz work a slightly different way to create adequate 'spring' to make the jaw close. This requires two flex areas.... just push down on the back/shoulder with the belly supported to make the jaws open and expose the teeth. The 'internal teeth' teeth make Wild Catz bite onto things really well!

This design also has friction between the moving parts of the jaw as it opens and closes so, when opened/closed slowly it creates a low pitched noise that could be interpreted as a growl (...or purr). Print one then move the jaws and listen... grrrrrr!

At standard size Wild Catz are approx. 12.5cm long x 6cm tall. The print only uses 22gm of filamen and takes 1.5 to 2 hours (depending on MakerBot model and settings). Your Wild Catz should come off the build plate ready to bit (feed) as soon as the raft is removed.

The design must be printed to be strong to ensure adequate spring/tension to close the jaw fully. The clearances designed in should work okay on most machines with PLA. If your print will not free the jaw/teeth increase the scale uniformly by approx. 5% as that will increase the internal spacing necessary to make the jaw move. Refer to the instructions for further details.

Note: If you like this check out all my other designs... and upload photos of your prints!

Also check out my other similar designs:

'Z-REX' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1594269

'Ratz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1532944

'Woodpeckerz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1155168

'Sharkz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:910216

'Crocz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941177

'Eaglez' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963892

'Catz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:988088

'Scorpionz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001286

'Fish Fossilz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1276095

'Snakez' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1709106

On a Replicator 2 Wild Catz print well as follows:

  • Raft ON
  • Std. Resolution (0.20mm)
  • 3 Shells
  • 75% infill
  • Supports OFF

On a 5th Generation MakerBot increasing the shells to 4 is recommended. .

introduce korea dabo-tower(tap)
Bulguksa Dabotap (Dabotap Pagoda of Bulguksa Temple)

Classification National Treasures 20
Designated Date 1962.12.20
Address Bulguksa. 15, Jinhyeon-dong Gyeongju-si Gyeongsangbuk-do
Age Unified Silla Period

Dabotap Pagoda and Seokgatap Pagoda (Sakyamuni pagoda) (Bulguksa Temple's three-story stone pagoda, National Treasure No.21) are the two representative pagodas in Korea.

The height of the two is the same of 10.4m.

The two pagodas stand facing each other at the yard, one in the east and the other in the west, between Hall of Sakyamuni and Jahamun Gate in Bulguksa Temple.

The one in the east is Dabotap Pagoda.

This pagoda is a representative special-type pagoda, and Seokgatap Pagoda (Sakyamuni pagoda) a representative general-type stone pagoda.

The reason of building the two pagodas at the same site is to follow the content of Beophwagyeong (the Lotus Sutra) that the 'past Buddha' Dabo Buddha is standing beside the 'present Buddha' Sakyamuni to prove that his Buddhist sermon is right.

Bulguksa Temple was founded by Kim Daeseong's offer in the 10th year (751) of King Gyeongdeok in Silla Era.

Samgungnyusa ("History of the Three Dynastys") says that Kim Daeseong built Seokguram Temple for his parents in his former life and Bulguksa Temple for his present parents.

However, the construction of this temple was not finished till he died, and so it was finished afterwards by the dynasty.

After all, the temple was built not for the individual Kim Daeseong but for the dynasty.

Bulguksa Temple can be said to be the materialized Buddhist Elysium, or paradise where the past, present, and future Buddhist monks live.

It shows the spirit world of the people in Silla Era very well. We can easily see that Seokgatap Pagoda (Sakyamuni pagoda) is a 3-story pagoda standing on 2-story platform.

But It is difficult to count the number of stories in Dabotap Pagoda.

In fact, even experts have confusing opinions, some saying it is 4-story, others saying it is 3-story.

However, the uniqueness of Dabotap Pagoda can be found at the structure of each part. In the whole figure, 2-story rooms as pagoda body stand on the platform, and head decorations are on the top.

The planes are cut to be square at the platform, and octagonal at the parts above it.

Uniquely, it seems that there were stone staircases with guardrails on the four direction of the platform.

But only stone pillars are left on both sides presently.

They built the octagonal pagoda body after surrounding square guardrails around it.

And they carved octagonal guardrails, bamboo joint-shaped stone pillars, and sixteen pieces of lotus flower design on the pagoda body.

The skill is so excellent that we can't imagine they carved from stones.

The head decoration of Seokgatap Pagoda (Sakyamuni pagoda) is a restored one, while that of Dabotap Pagoda almost perfectly remains as it used to be. This work is a masterpiece that excellently expresses the complicated structure of wooden construction without distraction through novel ideas.

The work evidently shows the artistic essence of the United Silla Dynasty in that it has the well-organized structure using squares, octagons, and circles, and in that the length, width and thickness are standardized in every part.

The pagoda seems to have been built in 751 when Bulguksa Temple was freshly remodeled with a large scale. It is unfortunate that Dabotap Pagoda entirely contaire at the platform, and octagonal at the parts above it.

Uniquely, it seems that there were stone staircases with guardrails on the four direction of the platform.

But only stone pillars are left on both sides presently.

They built the octagonal pagoda body after surrounding square guardrails around it.

And they carved octagonal guardrails, bamboo joint-shaped stone pillars, and sixteen pieces of lotus flower design on the pagoda body.

The skill is so excellent that we can't imagine they carved from stones.

The head decoration of Seokgatap Pagoda (Sakyamuni pagoda) is a restored one, while that of Dabotap Pagoda almost perfectly remains as it used to be. This work is a masterpiece that excellently expresses the complicated structure of wooden construction without distraction through novel ideas.

The work evidently shows the artistic essence of the United Silla Dynasty in that it has the well-organized structure using squares, octagons, and circles, and in that the length, width and thickness are standardized in every part.

The pagoda seems to have been built in 751 when Bulguksa Temple was freshly remodeled with a large scale. It is unfortunate that Dabotap Pagoda entirely contains the sorrow that the people felt when the Japanese Empire deprived them of the country.

The Japanese dismantled and repaired the pagoda around 1925, but they didn't leave any record about this fact.

In the process, sarira, sarira casket and other relics that must have been put into the pagoda all disappeared.

And out of four lions that were on the stone staircases of the pagoda, the Japanese Empire robbed us of three lions that must have been in good condition.

Though we have long made efforts to retrieve the precious cultural properties, we can't find their trace yet.

description.text:
These are little brackets to make it easier to mount strings of festive lights on your house.  The first one installs in vented soffit panels.  Pinch the two "horns" gently to fit in a couple of the soffit vent holes and let it spring up to mount.  (Some vent patterns are different, your mileage may vary.)  I intentionally designed them without a latch so they're easy to remove & reposition.
The second bracket can be mounted with a #4 or 3mm flathead wood screw.
Once mounted, the cord for the light string slips through the gap in the ring.  For lots of lights, 4 or more strings should fit.  I space them about one every foot.
I designed them in ViaCAD Pro.

Because the rings are fairly narrow (2 mm square cross section), the default shell settings didn't work very well on my Thing-O-Matic. I went in to the SkeinForge parameters and set all Extra Shells parameters to 0, which seems to work. I found this article very helpful:
http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/05/31/untangling-skeinforge-shells/ If anyone has a better set of parameters, please let me know, there are a scary lot of knobs to tweak there. The ToM automated build platform is very useful for this, as you'll probably want a couple dozen or more. I can print about 8 of the small brackets per hour and 4 of the screw mounted ones in an hour.

title: Ultimate Replicator 1 Octave Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
First, I want to thank the amazing folks on Thingiverse who have designed and posted some amazing spool holders for the Replicator 1 to hold Octave spools of filament, which are available for cheap on Amazon.  
However, in my experience, I was not able to get a final printed example that worked very well.  When I did get one to print, it didn't do a very good job of holding my spools.  There was a lot of sagging of the spool, and some of the spool holders wouldn't fit into the hole on the back of my Replicator.  Some of them wouldn't print right because there was too much undercut which required support.  Some of them even required me to print out multiple parts and GLUE them together!  Maybe it is just me, but I didn't buy a 3D printer so I could glue pieces together!  ;)  
Overall, I was not satisfied with the selection I found.  I was frustrated.  
But I need a couple of really good spool holders.  
So what did I do?  Well, I'm a "maker"...so I built them myself!  
The spool holder "thing" presented here is designed from scratch in Autodesk Inventor (if you haven't played with Autodesk Inventor, get it...it is awesome...you can use it at TechShop for free, and you can get a free copy that you can use on your own computer for 6 months for free if you are a TechShop member!)  
I didn't attribute by spool holder to any other Thingiverse members, but that's because I literally took my own measurements from the printer and the spools and designed it myself in about 10 minutes.  
This "thing" is designed to print really well with the acetone/ABS slurry technique (to prevent curling) that I pioneered which you can search for here and on Inventables.  
This part requires no raft or support at all, and is very sturdy to hold a heavy spool full of brand new filament.  I printed it (and most everything I make) with 1 shell and 100% fill with a 0.17mm layer height.  
Even though there is an offset, the offset is designed in so that you can print the spool holder without support flat on the bed.  This spool holder works on either the right or left side, but if you really want symmetry, you can mirror this part and print it for the left spool of your Replicator.  I didn't bother.  
Enjoy!

I printed it with MakerWare on a Replicator 1 in ABS, 100% infill, 1 shell, and a layer height of 0.17mm.  
It hooks right in to a Replicator 1, and is extremely strong for the small amount of material is contains.

remixed_from.author: capitaenz
remixed_from.title: Adjustable Z endstop for Prusa (Microswitch) - easy to print

title: Yet Another Z Endstop Adjuster Prusa, RepRap, MakerGear

description.text: This adjuster is designed to go with the stock MakerGear Prusa Z endstop.  This one-piece design is very simple and yet functional.  I decided to place the adjustment screw at a thick part of the block so that's why it is asymmetrical.  This slides onto the ends of the smooth bars and is secured by 2- M3 screws from the bottom.  The adjustment screw goes through the M3 nut in the nut trap.  Once installed, you just need to lower the Z endstop by about 5 millimeters and swing it out to align the lever with the adjustment screw.  Fine adjustments are made by turning the adjustment screw.  This eliminates the need to tweak the Z offset in your slicer software.

Parts:
1x M3-.5 x 25 screw
1x M3-.5 nut
2x M3-.5 x 12 screws Tools:
Hand file,
X-Acto knife,
M3-.5 tap After your part is printed, you may need to use a file and/or X-Acto knife to clean the holes and the nut trap. You will also want to file the bottom of the adjustment screw to make sure that the part that touches the limit switch is smooth. Once the part has been cleaned up, insert the M3 nut into the nut trap. Next, thread the M3x25 adjustment screw through the nut until about 5mm is extended beyond the bottom edge of the printed part. Use your M3 tap to tap the 2 holes on the bottom. Slide the part onto the 2 smooth rods. If necessary, tap the block with a small hammer or mallet. This should be pretty snug but if you want, you can add the 2- M3x12 screws to secure the block to the smooth rods. Loosen the screw for the stock Z endstop holder and lower it by about 5mm. You will also need to swing out the Z endstop to align the lever with the screw. Tighten the Z endstop holder with the lever horizontal.

description.text:
Hello all to the development of the second version of the Beastgrip Remix. Normally I finish a project before posting but for this project I decided to take a different direction. This time around I want to build the next iteration through the notion of crowd sourcing for ideas and suggestions.

Progress of Project can be seen on my tumblr page.
http://sketchpunklabs.tumblr.com/tagged/BeastGripRemix

GOALS OF MARK2
~ Rail Frame Design : Main purpose is to allow flexibility in the overall rig. Ideally if you wanted a rig for a tiny phone just buy smaller rods, if you want to use you're 7 inch tablet just buy longer rods. Second is less parts to print, since the rods make up most of the frame. Third, two rails allows to easily attach things to the frame like camera arms or whatever else you can think of can be clamped onto the rails, slide around and screw tight into a position.

~ Different Handles : Going with a rail frame I would like to try to make the handles optional and varied. Initially I will try a more standard beastgrip handle and also one built using bicycle handles.

~ Battery Pack Support : Want a way to attach varied size/shape battery backs. When doing long photoshoots or video recording you need more power then your phone can normally support. So being able to attach a power supply to the rig while plugged into the phone will really make the unit last longer while working. Solar power battery pack for starters, solar takes forever to charge but if you're out for a few hours then its possible to buy a few extra minutes of charge which can always be useful.

~ Shutter Button : This is the big one. First version I used earbuds and Google Cardboard magnet switch. Earbuds volume up button worked the best but its not comfortable. Found tutorials on how to make you're own play/vol buttons for headphone cables, so using that knowledge I want to create a large shutter button that can be attached to the rig for better control of taking pictures, no touching the screen required.

~ Metric : And finally I want to use all metric screws, rods, etc on this build. First time around I used USA screws which is fine but this time around I want the rig to be easily built by anyone in the world, so metric is key, besides I have to model everything in metric anyway for 3d printing.

PROGRESS
The frame, Clamp and Lens mount are done with the first draft of the design.

TODO

  1. Make some handles.

  2. Create Shutter Button

  3. This is a big if but maybe use beastgrip's tutorial on how to make a DOF adapter. Need to price out the cost of the parts, it might be cheaper to just order one from beastgrip directly but I won't worry about this till the rig is complete.

ANY HELP
Not 100% ok with the design. The lens mount works but I need it to shave off 3-4mm of space. The big issue is the filter ring is 7mm tall and its what I'm using to screw in 37mm lenses. The distance has the corners show a little black which is the walls of the lens. If I put the lense right up to the phone camera it goes away. So I need at most 3mm of space but I have not been able to find a step up/down ring or filter that is thin, doesn't help that amazon does not give you that spec.

So any help or suggestions to improve what I have so far would be greatly appreciated.

LINKS
http://store.rc4wd.com/Solid-Links_c_33.html

BEYOND
After this project is done, or almost done I'm thinking about taking the frame rail design and apply it to a google cardboard design. I created something months ago but stop because I wasn't happy with the design and the parts took forever to print. But the frame design should make things very easy to put together and open up some design ideas. Oculus's consumer model is somewhat a frame design with clothy material over the whole frame, so the same can be possible for google cardboard. I already have the lenses and they work pretty well in the first two iterations of the vr goggles I made. So this frame design would be a perfect method to finish that project.

description.text:
Most of 3D printed prosthetic hand allow just one movement : Grasping.

Using the previous work of Lukas Gratwohl, who did a mechanical 3d printed prosthetic hand, this version now allows a switch between grasping and pinching, both movement we use daily.

The same prosthetic can be used to hold a bottle of water or a key :
We move forward into the improvement of cheap, efficient and 3d printed prosthetic hand.

None of this would have been possible without the help of the CVAP department of KTH Royal Institute of Technology, and my tutor in this department, Christian Smith.

The tendons are made of fishing line 0.50mm for the outer part, and of elastic O-ring 0.6mm inner diameter for the outer part

Fingers are fixed together using screws Ø3mm

Others parts are fixed with Ø4mm screws

You can use any type of blokers to block the fishing line

Use Velcro® to tight the prosthetic to the hand and wrist

Use a long and fine screw to assemble the switch part

title: Coin Organizer for Car Cup Holder

description.text:
Whenever I get change, I usually end up throwing it into one of my car's cupholders and it never really gets used. It just sits there. So, I decided to design a coin organizer that would fit inside my car's cupholder. It only took me about 15 minutes to design from start to finish. It did take me a while to slice the file and setup the printer settings just right. I used my local hackerspace's (HeatSync Labs) Ultimaker 3D printer. It printed really well and turned into a great piece that looks great and works even better. I am proud to have it in my car and use it to show off the practicality and awesomeness of 3D printing. This is something you can print, use a lot, and that your friends will definitely take notice of. 3D printing is a great emerging technology and I hope that others will print this and help spread the awesomeness of 3D printing.  
This car coin organizer can also hold items in the center or it can be used to hold up to seven pens or any combination of pens, coins, and/or other stuff.  
Thanks for looking and please comment.
Shoutout to my hackerspace HeatSync Labs for letting me use the Ultimaker 3D Printer. This ended up taking a couple hours to print.

title: Primesense Carmine v1.09 Glasses Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an adapter for mounting reading glass lenses in front of a Primesense Carmine v1.09 sensor in order to improve detail resolution. Use cheap +2.5 diopter plastic reading glasses, and cut 2cm squares from the center of each lens. Unlike other designs I saw that required using a hole saw to cut a circular lens piece, this fully parametric design simplifies the build by using square-cut lenses. Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73258

Print in PLA or ABS, with a 0.2mm layer height, using support, oriented so the lens openings face upwards. The lenses can be glued in place with a small dab of plastic cement in each corner of the cutouts.  
I purchased a 3-pack of +2.5 diopter, plastic-lens reading glasses from the drug store for about $15, and then used a scroll saw to cut the lenses to size. I printed 2cm square templates (included) onto a standard 4" x 2" label sheet, and stuck those onto the lenses to guide the cuts (and protect the lenses during the cut).   
I tried cutting the lenses with a hacksaw, dremel cutting wheel and electric scroll saw. I found that the scroll saw was the best option, easily cutting to size, without damaging the lenses.

title: Vacuum forming mold masters for making ice luminaries
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are prototypes for ice luminary (aka ice lantern) mold masters that I'm experimenting with for a friend at our local Makerspace.
As I understand it, the mold masters have plastic drawn down over them by a vacuum forming machine. The vacuum formed plastic parts are then filled with water and frozen. The ice is then removed from the mold and an LED "throwie" is placed in the pocket under each one.

These have to be kept fairly simple so that the mold master and the ice can be easily removed from the vacuum formed molds. These could also be used as-is if printed in T-Glase or some other transparent filament. But in that case, they could be made a lot more complicated because their would be no mold release constraints.

I may be adding or deleting files as they are tested. The Cavity for the LED throwie is about 27.5mm in diameter. If you need a bigger hole for an LED tea lamp, I suggest scaling up the entire part before printing by the appropriate amount.

Modeled in DesignSpark Mechanical

Print in the default orientation. The small central hole and funnel at the bottom is to allow an air passageway for the plastic to be drawn down in the cylindrical pocket where the LED throwie will be placed.

comments.text: You could also use silicone for the mold. Might be easier to get the ice out. We have done much vacuum forming and it can be quite hard getting the plastic off the tool.. (or ice out the plastic in your case) We were using .060 PETG..
